questions.question_text_1:
Consider a MLP network with 16 input nodes and 8 output nodes, where each output node is locally connected to exactly 4 input nodes (i.e., no parameter sharing).  
Each connection has: - A unique weight. - A unique bias for each output neuron. Assume: - Each weighted input (i.e., one multiplication) is counted as one operation. - Adding the bias to the weighted sum is one operation. - Do not count additional operations for summing or activation. What will be the total runtime and storage (total number of parameters) required?
question_texts:
Consider a MLP network with 16 input nodes and 8 output nodes, where each output node is locally connected to exactly 4 input nodes (i.e., no parameter sharing).  
Each connection has: - A unique weight. - A unique bias for each output neuron. Assume: - Each weighted input (i.e., one multiplication) is counted as one operation. - Adding the bias to the weighted sum is one operation. - Do not count additional operations for summing or activation. What will be the total runtime and storage (total number of parameters) required?

options.option_text: Runtime: 40 operations, Storage: 40 parameters.
Runtime: 64 operations, Storage: 32 parameters.
Runtime: 32 operations, Storage: 32 parameters.
Runtime: 40 operations, Storage: 8 parameters.

questions.question_text_1:
You are implementing Faster R-CNN, a two-stage object detection framework. The model consists of three main blocks: 
Block 1: Region Proposal Network (RPN): Generates region proposals for possible objects. Block 2: Backbone Network (Feature Extractor): Extracts feature maps from the input image. Block 3: ROI Head (Classification & Bounding Box Regression): Classifies the proposals and refines bounding box coordinates. 
Which of the following orders correctly arranges the blocks for a complete Faster R-CNN object detection pipeline?
question_texts:
You are implementing Faster R-CNN, a two-stage object detection framework. The model consists of three main blocks: 
Block 1: Region Proposal Network (RPN): Generates region proposals for possible objects. Block 2: Backbone Network (Feature Extractor): Extracts feature maps from the input image. Block 3: ROI Head (Classification & Bounding Box Regression): Classifies the proposals and refines bounding box coordinates. 
Which of the following orders correctly arranges the blocks for a complete Faster R-CNN object detection pipeline?

options.option_text: Block 2 → Block 1 → Block 3
Block 1 → Block 2 → Block 3
Block 3 → Block 2 → Block 1
Block 2 → Block 3 → Block 1
(a) and (b) are True; (c) and (d) are False.
(a), (b), and (d) are True; (c) is False.
(a) and (d) are True; (b) and (c) are False.
All statements are True.

questions.question_text_1: The Perceptual Loss Function in SRGAN is designed to improve the quality of super-resolved images by incorporating multiple loss components. Which of the following best describes the role of the loss function in SRGAN?
question_texts: The Perceptual Loss Function in SRGAN is designed to improve the quality of super-resolved images by incorporating multiple loss components. Which of the following best describes the role of the loss function in SRGAN?

options.option_text: Perceptual loss in SRGAN is purely based on pixel-wise differences and doesnot incorporate adversarial learning.
It combines adversarial loss (which helps differentiate real from generatedimages) and content loss (which enforces perceptual similarity instead of pixel-wise similarity).
Perceptual loss is applied only to the discriminator to improve its ability toclassify real vs. generated highresolution images.
It directly modifies the MSE loss function by adding a high-frequencyenhancement term to capture fine details.

question_texts: Consider the following two deep neural network blocks used in a convolutional neural network:

Consider the following two deep neural network blocks used in a convolutional neural network: 
  You train two deep neural networks, one using 50 stacked copies of Block A and another using 50 stacked copies of Block B. Both networks are initialized with random weights and trained on the same dataset. Which of the following is the most likely outcome, and why?

options.option_text: The network with Block A performs better because it contains more activationlayers, increasing model expressiveness.
The network with Block B achieves better convergence and higher accuracydue to improved gradient flow from residual connections.
Both networks perform similarly since they have the same number ofconvolutional layers.
The network with Block A struggles to train and may suffer from vanishinggradients, preventing effective learning.

questions.question_text_1: In depth estimation from stereo images, the disparity map plays a crucial role in computing depth information. Which of the following best describes its primary role?
question_texts: In depth estimation from stereo images, the disparity map plays a crucial role in computing depth information. Which of the following best describes its primary role?

options.option_text: The disparity map measures the horizontal displacement of correspondingpixels in the left and right images, allowing depth estimation through triangulation.
Lower disparity corresponds to greater depth.
The disparity map smooths the image intensities to improve feature matchingbefore depth computation.
The disparity map is independent of the camera’s intrinsic parameters and canbe used to compute depth without any additional information.

questions.question_text_1: In the GoogLeNet (Inception Network), 1×1 convolutional filters play a crucial role in improving performance and efficiency. Which of the following statements correctly describe the importance of 1×1 convolutions in GoogLeNet?
question_texts: In the GoogLeNet (Inception Network), 1×1 convolutional filters play a crucial role in improving performance and efficiency. Which of the following statements correctly describe the importance of 1×1 convolutions in GoogLeNet?

options.option_text: 1×1 convolutions reduce the number of input channels before applying largerconvolutional filters, thereby reducing computational cost.
They help in learning spatial features by increasing the receptive field beforedeeper convolutions.
1×1 convolutions serve as a bottleneck layer that helps reduce the number ofparameters in the network.
They are primarily used to replace fully connected layers, transforming denseconnections into convolutional operations.
1×1 convolutions are only used in the final layers of the network forclassification and do not contribute to feature extraction.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements about U-Net-based depth estimation from a single image: Which of the following statements are NOT true? (Select all that apply)
question_texts: Consider the following statements about U-Net-based depth estimation from a single image: Which of the following statements are NOT true? (Select all that apply)

options.option_text: U-Net-based depth estimation always produces high-resolution depth mapswithout any artifacts.
The U-Net architecture is inherently designed for segmentation tasks, so itrequires modification in the loss function for depth estimation.
Skip connections in U-Net help recover spatial details, but they do notcontribute to improved depth accuracy.
U-Net-based depth estimation models can work well even without anysupervised training.
U-Net follows an encoder-decoder structure, where the encoder extractsfeatures and the decoder reconstructs depth information.

questions.question_text_1: The LAKDNet architecture is designed for efficient feature extraction by leveraging novel convolutional techniques. Consider the following statements about LAKDNet. Which of the following statements are NOT true about LAKDNet?
question_texts: The LAKDNet architecture is designed for efficient feature extraction by leveraging novel convolutional techniques. Consider the following statements about LAKDNet. Which of the following statements are NOT true about LAKDNet?

options.option_text: LAKDNet is similar to depth-wise separable convolution, utilizing unusuallylarge kernel sizes (e.g., 9×9).
It incorporates a point-wise convolution (1×1) to enhance channel-wise featureinteractions.
LAKDNet uses normal convolution kernel to jointly process spatial intrachannel and depth wise inter-channel features
Its key advantage is enabling distant spatial location mixture while reducingcomputational complexity.
Compared to normal convolutions, the depthwise and pointwise convolutionsin LAKDNet require more parameters.

question_texts: Consider the following PyTorch code snippet:

Consider the following PyTorch code snippet: 
  Which of the following statements correctly describe the output shape of the convolution operation?

options.option_text: The output size reduces to 5 x 5 due to the 3 x 3 kernel, stride of (2,2), andpadding of 1.
The output size reduces to 4 x 4 because of the (3 x 3) filter, stride of (2,2), andpadding of 1.
The convolution operation cannot be performed because the filter size mustbe smaller than the stride.
The padding increases the effective receptive field, but the output size remains4 x 4 due to the stride and kernel size constraints.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements about VGG. Which of the following all TRUE (Select all that apply)
question_texts: Consider the following statements about VGG. Which of the following all TRUE (Select all that apply)

options.option_text: Most of the memory consumption in VGG comes from the early convolutionallayers, where feature maps are large.
The majority of trainable parameters in VGG are located in the **fullyconnected (FC) layers** rather than the convolutional layers.
The depth of VGG is the primary reason for its **low memory requirements,making it computationally efficient.
Reducing the number of filters in later layers would significantly decrease thetotal trainable parameters while keeping the memory footprint unchanged.
VGG uses 1×1 convolutions extensively to reduce the number of parametersand improve computational efficiency.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Deep Learning Practices** exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary**
### **1. Neural Network Architectures**
#### **Key Architectures Covered:**
- **VGGNet**
  - Uses small (3×3) convolutional filters with deep stacks (16–19 layers).
  - Most parameters are in **fully connected (FC) layers** (not convolutional layers).
  - Memory-heavy due to large feature maps in early layers.
  - **Modification for custom tasks**:
    - Replace the last FC layer (`classifier[6]`) to match output classes.
    - Example (PyTorch):
      ```python
      self.vgg.classifier[6] = nn.Linear(4096, num_classes)  # Correct (Option A in Q2)
      ```
  - **Key Equation (Output Size)**:
    For input size \( W \times H \), kernel \( K \), stride \( S \), padding \( P \):
    \[
    \text{Output Size} = \left\lfloor \frac{W + 2P - K}{S} \right\rfloor + 1
    \]

- **AlexNet**
  - Uses **3×3 max-pooling with stride 2** (default).
  - **Modification Example** (Q3):
    ```python
    nn.MaxPool2d(kernel_size=3, stride=2, padding=1)  # Correct (Option A)
    ```

- **GoogLeNet (Inception)**
  - Uses **1×1 convolutions** to:
    - Reduce computational cost (bottleneck layers).
    - Mix channel-wise features before larger convolutions.
  - **Naive Inception Module** (Q4):
    - Parallel convolutions (1×1, 3×3, 5×5, pooling) concatenated along channels.
    - Correct implementation (Option A):
      ```python
      self.branch1x1 = nn.Conv2d(in_channels, 64, kernel_size=1)
      self.branch3x3 = nn.Sequential(nn.Conv2d(in_channels, 64, kernel_size=3, padding=1))
      self.branch5x5 = nn.Sequential(nn.Conv2d(in_channels, 64, kernel_size=5, padding=2))
      self.branch_pool = nn.MaxPool2d(kernel_size=3, stride=1, padding=1)
      ```

- **ResNet**
  - **Residual connections** mitigate vanishing gradients (Q12).
  - Block B (with skip connection) converges faster than Block A (plain stack).

- **U-Net**
  - **Encoder-decoder** with **skip connections** for spatial detail recovery.
  - Used in **depth estimation/segmentation** (Q17).
  - **Not true**:
    - Skip connections don’t improve depth accuracy (C).
    - Works without supervised training (D).
    - Always artifact-free (A).

- **Faster R-CNN**
  - **Order of blocks** (Q9):
    1. **Backbone (Feature Extractor)** → 2. **RPN (Region Proposal)** → 3. **ROI Head (Classification + BBox Regression)**.
  - Correct order: **Block 2 → Block 1 → Block 3 (Option A)**.

- **YOLO (You Only Look Once)**
  - **Mistake in implementation** (Q8):
    - Bounding box coordinates (\(x, y, w, h\)) must be **scaled to absolute pixels** (Option A).

- **RCNN vs. Fast R-CNN vs. YOLO**
  - **RCNN** (Q14): Crops regions → CNN → SVM classifier (slow).
  - **Fast R-CNN**: Shares CNN features across regions (faster).
  - **YOLO**: Single forward pass for detection (real-time).

---

### **2. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Convolution Operation** (Q6, Q20):
  - Output size formula (see above).
  - Example (Q6):
    - Input: 128×128×3, 32 filters (5×5), stride=2, padding=1.
    - Output: **64×64×32** (Option A).
  - Example (Q20):
    - Input: 8×8, kernel=3×3, stride=2, padding=1 → Output: **4×4** (Options B/D).

- **Pooling Operations** (Q3, Q15):
  - **Max Pooling**: Default in AlexNet (3×3, stride=2, padding=1).
  - **Min Pooling** (Q15):
    - Input (5×5), kernel=3×3, stride=1 → Output:
      ```
      [[0, 0, 0],
       [0, 0, 0],
       [0, 0, 0]]
      ```
      (Option C).

- **Disparity Maps** (Q13):
  - Measures **horizontal pixel displacement** between stereo images for depth estimation via triangulation.
  - **Lower disparity → Greater depth**.

---

### **3. Object Detection Metrics**
#### **Key Metrics:**
- **Intersection over Union (IoU)** (Q10):
  \[
  \text{IoU} = \frac{\text{Area of Overlap}}{\text{Area of Union}}
  \]
  - Range: [0, 1].
  - IoU=1 → Identical boxes (B).
  - No overlap → IoU=0 (C is false).
  - Independent of image size (D).

- **Precision & F1-Score** (Q7):
  - **Precision**: \(\frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FP}}\).
  - **Recall**: \(\frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FN}}\).
  - **F1-Score**: \(2 \times \frac{\text{Precision} \times \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}}\).
  - Example (Q7):
    - **Macro-average Precision**: (1.0 + 0.8 + 0.6 + 0.8)/4 = **0.8**.
    - **Macro-average F1-Score**: 0.8 (Option B).

---

### **4. Loss Functions & Optimization**
- **Perceptual Loss (SRGAN)** (Q11):
  - Combines:
    - **Adversarial loss** (GAN-based realism).
    - **Content loss** (perceptual similarity via deep features, not pixel-wise MSE).
  - Correct: **Option B**.

- **Local Connections (Q5)**:
  - **MLP with local connections** (no weight sharing):
    - Each output connects to 4 inputs → **4 weights + 1 bias per output**.
    - Total parameters: \(8 \text{ outputs} \times (4 \text{ weights} + 1 \text{ bias}) = 40\).
    - Runtime: \(16 \text{ inputs} \times 4 \text{ ops} + 8 \text{ biases} = 40 \text{ ops}\).
    - Correct: **Option A**.

---

### **5. Image Processing**
- **Noise Addition** (Q18):
  - **Uniform noise [10, 30]** to 8-bit image (0–255):
    - Use `np.random.uniform` + `np.clip` + `astype(np.uint8)`.
    - Correct: **Options C/D**.
    - Example (C):
      ```python
      noise = np.random.uniform(10, 30, image.shape)
      noisy_image = np.clip(image.astype(np.float32) + noise, 0, 255).astype(np.uint8)
      ```

---

### **6. Advanced CNNs**
- **LAKDNet** (Q19):
  - Uses **large kernel depth-wise separable convolutions** (e.g., 9×9).
  - **Not true**:
    - Uses normal convolution (C).
    - More parameters than standard convolutions (E).

- **Depthwise Separable Convolutions** (Q16):
  - **1×1 convolutions** in GoogLeNet:
    - Reduce channels before 3×3/5×5 convs (A).
    - Act as bottleneck layers (C).

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. CNN Architectures Relationship**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[CNN Architectures] --> B[VGGNet]
    A --> C[AlexNet]
    A --> D[GoogLeNet/Inception]
    A --> E[ResNet]
    A --> F[U-Net]
    A --> G[Faster R-CNN]
    A --> H[YOLO]

    B --> B1["Small 3x3 filters"]
    B --> B2["Deep stacks (16-19 layers)"]
    B --> B3["FC layers dominate parameters"]

    C --> C1["3x3 max-pooling"]
    C --> C2["Stride=2, padding=1"]

    D --> D1["1x1 convolutions"]
    D --> D2["Parallel branches (Inception Module)"]
    D --> D3["Reduces computational cost"]

    E --> E1["Residual connections"]
    E --> E2["Mitigates vanishing gradients"]

    F --> F1["Encoder-decoder"]
    F --> F2["Skip connections"]

    G --> G1["RPN → Backbone → ROI Head"]
    G --> G2["Two-stage detection"]

    H --> H1["Single-stage detection"]
    H --> H2["Grid-based predictions"]
```

### **2. Object Detection Pipeline**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Input Image] --> B[Backbone CNN]
    B --> C[Region Proposals]
    C --> D[RPN]
    D --> E[ROI Pooling]
    E --> F[Classification]
    E --> G[Bounding Box Regression]
    F --> H[Final Detections]
    G --> H
```

### **3. Loss Functions in GANs/SRGAN**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[SRGAN Loss] --> B[Adversarial Loss]
    A --> C[Content Loss]
    B --> B1["Discriminator guides generator"]
    C --> C1["VGG features for perceptual similarity"]
    C --> C2["Avoids pixel-wise MSE"]
```

### **4. Pooling & Convolution Operations**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Convolution/Pooling] --> B[Output Size Calculation]
    A --> C[Stride]
    A --> D[Padding]
    A --> E[Kernel Size]
    B --> B1["Floor[(W + 2P - K)/S] + 1"]
    C --> C1["Stride=2 halves spatial dims"]
    D --> D1["Padding=1 preserves spatial dims if S=1"]
```

### **5. Evaluation Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Object Detection Metrics] --> B[IoU]
    A --> C[Precision]
    A --> D[Recall]
    A --> E[F1-Score]
    B --> B1["Overlap/Union"]
    B --> B2["Range: [0,1]"]
    C --> C1["TP/(TP+FP)"]
    D --> D1["TP/(TP+FN)"]
    E --> E1["Harmonic mean of Precision/Recall"]
```
